questions.text: Which of the following is an example of a vaccine used as a secondary level of prevention?

choices.text: Hepatitis B vaccine
MMR (Measles, Mumps, Rubella) vaccine
BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) vaccine
Influenza vaccine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) vaccine

Explanation:

Vaccination is a primary level of prevention - provides specific protection against diseases, before they occur.

Exception is the BCG (Bacillus Calmette-Guérin) vaccine

  • It is used against TB as a primary preventive measure.
  • But, it is also used to treat bladder cancer.
    • It is instilled intravesically
    • Targets existing cancer cells and prevents the progression and recurrence of bladder cancer.

Since the BCG vaccine is used for intervention, it is regarded as a secondary level of preventive measure.

Hepatitis B vaccine, MMR vaccine, and Influenza vaccine are all used to prevent infections in individuals before they occur, fitting the primary prevention model.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old child is brought by his mother. During the consultation, it is revealed that the child has not received any vaccinations since birth due to the family's geographical isolation and lack of access to healthcare services. The healthcare worker is concerned about the child’s susceptibility to vaccine-preventable diseases and advises immediate initiation of the vaccination schedule.

Based on this scenario, how would you classify this child’s immunization status?

choices.text: Fully immunized
Completely immunized
Dropout
Left out

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Left out

Explanation:

Here, the child has not been immunized since birth, so vaccination never reached this child. Hence, he will be classified as a left-out.

  • Fully immunised (Option A): A child who received all due vaccines according to the National Immunisation Schedule (NIS) up to the age of 1 year.
  • Completely immunised (Option B): A child who received all due vaccines according to NIS up to 12 to 23 months of age.
  • Dropouts (Option C): Incomplete complete immunisation. Children who started the vaccination schedule but did not complete it (discontinued).

questions.text: Which of the following vaccines cannot be given to a pregnant woman?

choices.text: Rabies vaccine
IPV
Rotavirus vaccine
Kyasanur Forest Disease Vaccine

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Rotavirus vaccine

Explanation:

Live attenuated vaccines contain weakened forms of pathogens that can replicate within the host and are contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • A live organism is injected into the body in attenuated form.
  • Attenuated form means that we have reduced the organism's virulence (killing power), but immunogenicity (antibody-producing capacity) is maintained.
  • The rotavirus vaccine is an example of a live attenuated vaccine designed to provide immunity against rotavirus infections.

 

Comparison of Live and Killed Vaccines:

Live Vaccines

Killed Vaccines

Injected in live, attenuated (weakened) form

Injected in killed form

A single dose is sufficient (except OPV)

Multiple doses are needed

Longer duration of immunity

Shorter duration of immunity

Contraindicated in pregnancy, radiation therapy, and severe symptomatic immunodeficiency.

It can be given during pregnancy

Examples:

Mnemonic - I love Chick EMBRYO

Live Influenza, Chickenpox (Varicella), Live JE vaccine, MR, BCG, Rotavirus, Yellow fever virus, OPV.

Others: Live plague vaccine

Examples:

Mnemonic: KILLED

KFD, IPV, Killed Influenza, Japanese Encephalitis (Killed), Dog bite-Rabies

Others · Killed Plague vaccine · Killed cholera vaccine

Reversion to virulence is possible.

Reversion to virulence is not possible.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is wrong with regard to administration of two live vaccines?

choices.text: Do not administer both vaccines at the same site simultaneously.
Administer both vaccines at different sites simultaneously.
Administer both vaccines with a minimum interval of 3 weeks.
Administer both vaccines with a minimum interval of 2 weeks.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Administer both vaccines with a minimum interval of 2 weeks.

Explanation:

The minimum time interval needed to administer two live vaccines is not 2 weeks.

Two live vaccines can be administered:

  • Simultaneously at different sites, or
  • With a minimum interval of 3 weeks between the vaccines, if required.

An example of simultaneous administration at different sites is as follows:

According to the National Immunization Schedule (NIS) at 9 completed months,

  • Measles-rubella: Right arm
  • Japanese Encephalitis: Left arm
  • Both administered as 0.5 ml via the subcutaneous route.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about polysaccharide vaccines?

choices.text: They are often combined with a toxoid component to enhance the immune response against toxins produced by bacteria.
Multiple immunizing agents are included in the vaccine.
More effective in children < 2 years
Polysaccharide based vaccines are available against S.pneumoniae, H.influenza b

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Polysaccharide based vaccines are available against S.pneumoniae, H.influenza b

Explanation:

Polysaccharide vaccines

  • Stimulate an antibody response against the capsular polysaccharides of pathogenic bacteria.
  • Disadvantage - serotype specific immune response since the capsular polysaccharides vary between different strains.
  • Polysaccharide-based vaccines are available against 23 serotypes of S.pneumoniae, Hib, Neisseria meningitidis, and Salmonella typhimurium.
  • Pneumococcal Polysaccharide Vaccine (PPV) is not used in NIS.

Other Subunit vaccines:

 

Vaccine and Mechanism

Examples

Advantage / Disadvantage

Toxoid

(Option A)

Exotoxins produced by live organisms are used

Diphtheria, Tetanus, Anthrax

Highly efficacious

Highly safe

Protein vaccine

Specific proteins or peptides from the pathogen

Influenza vaccine (hemagglutinin and Neuraminidase), Acellular pertussis vaccine.

Less immunogenic

Conjugate vaccine

Polysaccharide antigen chemically linked to a protein recognized by Tcells.

Pneumococcal conjugate vaccine - PCV (used in NIS), Meningococcal.

Adv: More effective in children < 2 years (Option C)

D/A: Serotype specific

Recombinant Vaccine

Prepared by DNA technology.

Antigens are expressed on E. coli, yeast, and mammalian cells.

Hepatitis B, HPV, Cholera toxin B, Lyme disease

Adv: Safe

D/A: Less immunogenic and need an adjuvant to enhance efficiency

Combination Vaccine

(Option B)

More than one immunizing agent

MMR, DPT, Pentavalent

Overall reduction in adverse effects due to combination

questions.text: Which of the following statements is FALSE regarding the contraindications of vaccines?

choices.text: Yellow fever vaccine can be given to pregnant women
DPT Vaccine is unsafe in children with Spina bifida
All live vaccines are contraindicated in patients on corticosteroids
All vaccines except MMR, measles, rubella & varicella are contraindicated in adults with symptomatic HIV

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) DPT Vaccine is unsafe in children with Spina bifida

Explanation:

DPT is safe for children with Spina bifida.

  • DPT is contraindicated in progressive neurological diseases due to its pertussis component, anaphylaxis to the previous dose, and encephalopathy within 7 days of vaccination attributed to no other cause. 
  • Post-vaccine fever, inconsolable cry within 48 hours, and seizures within 72 hours of vaccine are relative contraindications of DPT.
  • Spina Bifida is a birth defect where there is incomplete closing of the backbone and membranes around the spinal cord. It is a non-progressive neurological condition.
  • Hence DPT is safe in such patients.

All live vaccines are contraindicated in pregnancy except the yellow fever vaccine (Option A) as the infection's risk outweighs the live vaccine's risk.

All Live vaccines are contraindicated in patients on corticosteroids (Option C) since their immune response is suppressed.

All vaccines except MMR, measles, rubella & varicella are contraindicated in adults with symptomatic HIV (Option D) whereas none are contraindicated in asymptomatic HIV patients.

Contraindications of vaccines:

questions.text: A 7 y/o girl is brought to a makeshift medical camp that was set up following a massive earthquake 3 days ago. She has no prior history of vaccinations. The child was exposed to a confirmed case of measles two days ago. Which of the following would be your next step in helping the child?

choices.text: Administer the measles vaccine immediately.
Administer typhoid and cholera vaccines first.
Administer OPV.
No vaccines are necessary at this time.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Administer the measles vaccine immediately.
 

Explanation:

In a disaster scenario, all vaccines are contraindicated for victims except the measles vaccine, which can be administered within 3 days of exposure to a confirmed case.

This is because measles has a natural incubation period of 10-14 days, and antibodies can be produced after vaccination within 7 to 10 days, which can help in preventing the disease and its outbreak.

Typhoid and cholera vaccines (Option B) are not given to all because the time needed to produce antibodies is longer than the natural incubation period of these diseases.

In a disaster situation, immediate protection is crucial, and these vaccines do not offer quick enough protection to be beneficial in the acute phase.

OPV (Option C) is not indicated in this scenario unless there is an outbreak of polio- in which case OPV is given to at least 500 children in the vicinity.

 

Vaccine protocol during a disaster & Epidemic:

questions.text:
Match the following vaccines with their well-known side effects:

 


	
		
			
			Vaccine
			
			
			Side effect
			
		
		
			
			a. Rotavirus
			
			
			1. Inconsolable cry & convulsions
			
		
		
			
			b. BCG
			
			
			2. Toxic Shock Syndrome
			
		
		
			
			c. Measles
			
			
			3. Scar
			
		
		
			
			d. Pertussis
			
			
			4. Intussusception
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) a-4, b-3, c-2, d-1

Explanation:

  • Rotavirus vaccine usually causes intussusception 1 year after vaccination: The rotavirus vaccine induces an immune response that can lead to lymphoid hyperplasia, which is the enlargement of lymphoid tissue in the intestinal wall. This can create a lead point for intussusception.​ 
  • BCG Vaccine- scar.   

          Mechanism:

  • Measles is commonly associated with Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) - TSS occurs when the measles vaccine is contaminated or the same vial is used for more than 1 session on the same day or the next day. 
  • Pertussis- Inconsolable cry & convulsions is a known side-effect

Vaccines & their side effects:

questions.text: Which of the following is the diluent used for the Measles Rubella vaccine?

choices.text: Normal Saline
Phosphate Buffer Solution
Distilled water/ Sterile Water
Cold Physiological saline

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Distilled water/ Sterile Water

Explanation:

  • The diluent used for the Measles Rubella vaccine is Distilled water/ sterile water.
  • The diluent provided along with the vaccine by the manufacturer ONLY should be used.

Normal Saline (Option A)- is the diluent for the BCG Vaccine.

Phosphate Buffer Solution (Option B)- is the diluent used for Japanese encephalitis vaccine

Cold Physiological saline (Option D)- is the diluent used for Yellow fever Vaccine

Powdered vaccines & their diluents

questions.text: You have been posted in a rural PHC where you just received a new batch of vaccines for the upcoming vaccination drive. You need to educate your team on the conditions that have to be fulfilled in order to reuse opened vaccine vials during the drive. Which of the following would you not suggest regarding the same?

choices.text: The Vaccine Vial monitor has not reached the discard point.
An aseptic technique must be used to withdraw all doses.
Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+6° C to +10° C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point.
The expiry date should not have passed.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Vaccines are stored strictly under an appropriate temperature (+6° C to +10° C) range during transportation and storage at cold chain point
 

Explanation:

  • Here, we need to explain the conditions for fulfilling the Open Vial Policy; this statement is not true.
  • Under Open Vial Policy, Vaccines are stored at an appropriate temperature range of (+2°C to +8°C) during transportation & storage at cold chain points.
  • Other conditions to be fulfilled under open vial policy include:
  • The Vaccine Vial monitor has not reached the discard point (Option A): Monitoring the Vaccine vial Monitor (VVM) is an essential aspect of vaccine management followed under the Open Vial Policy
  • An aseptic technique must be used to withdraw all doses (Option B): Maintaining sterility during the withdrawal of the vaccine is important to prevent contamination, a requirement under the Open vial policy.
  • The expiry date has not passed (Option D): Expired vaccines can lose their efficacy and can even become harmful.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true based on thermolability of vaccines?

choices.text: The most heat-sensitive vaccine is Hepatitis B.
The most freeze-sensitive vaccine is Pentavalent.
The loss of potency of vaccines due to exposure to heat or cold is permanent and cannot be regained.
The physical appearance of a damaged vaccine always changes.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) The loss of potency of vaccines due to exposure to heat or cold is permanent and cannot be regained.

Explanation:-

Loss of potency due to either exposure to heat or cold is permanent and cannot be regained.

  • The most heat-sensitive vaccine is Reconstituted BCG>OPV>Measles (Option A)
  • The most freeze-sensitive vaccine is Hepatitis B>Pentavalent>DPT/Td (Option B)
  • The physical appearance of the vaccine may remain unchanged even after it is damaged. (Option C)


 

Vaccines Sensitive to Heat

Vaccines Sensitive to Freezing

OPV

Hepatitis B

IPV

Pentavalent

Measles, MR

IPV

Rota

DPT

JE

DT

DPT

  

BCG

  

TT

questions.text: Which of the following statements about the Vaccine Vial Monitor (VVM) is incorrect?

choices.text: The VVM is a heat-sensitive chemical indicator placed on the body of the vial, neck of the ampule, or cap of the vial.
The VVM records cumulative heat exposure of the vaccines through a gradual change in color.
If the inner square of the VVM is darker than the outer circle, the vaccine can still be used.
The VVM number is the time in days for the inner square to reach the colour indicating a discard point, if the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) If the inner square of the VVM is darker than the outer circle, the vaccine can still be used.

Explanation:

If the inner square of the VVM is darker than the outer circle, it indicates that the vaccine has been exposed to excessive heat and should not be used. Therefore, the statement that the vaccine can still be used is wrong.

VVM is only used to detect the potency of vaccine and it has nothing to do with expiry. If the vaccine is expired, it has to be discarded irrespective of the colour changes on VVM.

The VVM is indeed a heat-sensitive chemical indicator that is placed on the vial, ampule, or cap to monitor the vaccine's exposure to heat.(Option A)

The VVM changes color gradually to indicate the cumulative exposure of the vaccine to heat over time. (Option B)

The VVM numbers such as VVM2, VVM7, etc. is the time in days for the inner square to reach the colour indicating a discard point, if the vial is exposed to a constant temperature of 37°C. (Option D)

questions.text: Which of the following steps is incorrect when conducting a shake test to check for vaccine vial damage due to freezing?

choices.text: Take a vaccine vial you suspect may have been frozen and label it as the "Test" vial.
Freeze a control vial of the same antigen, manufacturer, and batch number at -20°C overnight, and label it as the "Frozen control vial."
Thaw the "Frozen control vial" by heating it gently.
Shake both the "Test" vial and the "Frozen control vial" together for 10-15 seconds, then place them side-by-side on a flat surface to observe sedimentation.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Thaw the "Frozen control vial" by heating it gently

Explanation:

The correct procedure is to let the "Frozen control vial" thaw naturally. Heating it can alter the results of the shake test.

  • Aluminium hydroxide present in dpt precipitates when frozen.

Shake test is used to check whether the vaccine vials have been damaged by exposure to below-zero temperatures.

questions.text: Which of the following diseases is not part of the Pan-India diseases covered under Mission Indradhanush?

choices.text: Extra-pulmonary tuberculosis
Polio
Rotavirus diarrhea
Japanese encephalitis

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Japanese encephalitis

Explanation:

Japanese encephalitis is included only in endemic areas and not part of the 11 diseases covered throughout India under Mission Indradhanush.

  • Mission Indradhanush 1.0 was launched in 2014 with the objective of 7 diseases, representing 7 colors of Rainbow.
  • Mission Indradhanush 2.0 was launched in 2019, covering 11 diseases and 1 endemic disease of Japanese Encephalitis.
  • Mission Indradhanush 3.0 was launched in 2021, to cover up dropouts during Covid.

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in the IT initiatives under Mission Indradhanush?

choices.text: eVIN (Electronic Vaccine Intelligence Network)
ANMOL (Auxiliary Nurse Midwife Online)
SAFE-VAC (Surveillance and Actions for Events following Vaccination)
AEFI (Adverse Event Following Immunization)

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) AEFI (Adverse Event Following Immunization)

Explanation:-

AEFI is not listed as one of the IT initiatives under Mission Indradhanush. It is a separate program under WHO that monitors adverse events following immunization, but it is not categorized as an IT initiative under Mission Indradhanush.

eVIN App (Option A)

  • IT initiative under Mission Indradhanush designed to strengthen immunization supply chain systems in India.
  • Helps in effective vaccine logistics management, including route planning, vaccine requirements, stock inventory, and stock reallocation.

ANMOL (Option B)

  • IT initiative under Mission Indradhanush that acts as a job aid for Auxiliary Nurse Midwives (ANMs).
  • Provides readily available information such as due lists, dashboards, guidance based on data entered, and educational videos on topics like high-risk pregnancy, immunization, and family planning.

SAFE-VAC (Option C)

  • IT initiative under Mission Indradhanush focused on monitoring and managing adverse events following vaccination.
  • It aims to enhance the safety and effectiveness of immunization programs by providing a system for the timely reporting, tracking, and analysis of any adverse events that occur after vaccination

questions.text: Which of the following statements is TRUE regarding the "Switch" from tOPV to bOPV in India?

choices.text: The switch included the removal of wpv1 from the vaccine formulation.
The reason for the switch was the eradication of wpv3 in September 2015.
bOPV contains attenuated forms of wpv1 and wpv3.
IPV was introduced after the switch to compensate for the removal of wpv2 from the vaccine.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) bOPV contains attenuated forms of wpv1 and wpv3.

Explanation:

The Switch:

  • This was approved because the wpv2 in tOPV was leading to CVDPV (Circulating Vaccine Derived Polio virus) which was dangerous and causing outbreaks. It was eradicated in September 2015.
  • wpv3 is associated with VAPP(vaccine-associated paralytic polio); it does not cause outbreaks. It was eradicated in October 2019. To maintain immunity against type 3 components, it is retained in bOPV.

This statement is false because the Switch involved the removal of wpv2, not wpv1, from the vaccine formulation(Option A)

This is also a false statement because the Switch was prompted by the eradication of wpv2 in 2015, not wpv3 (which was eradicated later in October 2019)(Option B)

IPV was introduced before the switch (in 2014-2015) to help maintain immunity against polio, particularly against the type 2 component(Option D)
